planInformation.title: Plan Information
planInformation.description: Let's start by setting up the basic information for your business continuity plan.

companyName.label: Company Name
companyName.prompt: What is the name of your company?
examples: ABC Store
Caribbean Delights
Island Services Ltd.

planManager.label: Plan Manager
planManager.prompt: Who is the person responsible for this business continuity plan? This should be someone with authority to make decisions.
examples: John Perez, Owner
Maria Rodriguez, Operations Manager
David Thompson, General Manager

alternateManager.label: Alternate Manager (Optional)
alternateManager.prompt: Who is the alternate person responsible if the main manager is unavailable? This field is optional - if you don't have an alternate manager, you can leave this blank or enter "N/A". Consider designating a trusted employee, family member, or business partner who can make basic decisions during emergencies.
examples: Sara Johnson, Assistant Manager
Michael Brown, Supervisor
Lisa Williams, Senior Staff
N/A - Will rely on main manager only
Will designate when business grows
Emergency contact: Local business association

physicalPlanLocation.label: Physical Plan Location
physicalPlanLocation.prompt: Where will physical copies of this business continuity plan be stored? Choose secure, accessible locations that multiple people can access.
examples: Fire-proof cabinet in manager's office
Security safe in reception area
Locked filing cabinet in administration office
Safety deposit box at local bank

digitalPlanLocation.label: Digital Plan Location
digitalPlanLocation.prompt: Where will digital copies be stored? This is optional - if you don't have reliable internet or digital storage, you can skip this field.
examples: Company server with daily backups
Google Drive shared with management team
Cloud storage with backup on external drive
Email copies sent to key personnel

planName.label: Plan Name
planName.prompt: What would you like to call this business continuity plan?
examples: Caribbean Breeze Restaurant Business Continuity Plan
Island Tech Solutions Emergency Response Plan
Paradise Tours & Travel Disaster Recovery Plan

businessName.label: Business Name
businessName.prompt: What is the official name of your business?
examples: Caribbean Breeze Restaurant Ltd.
Island Tech Solutions
Paradise Tours & Travel Co.

businessAddress.label: Business Address
businessAddress.prompt: What is the physical address of your main business location?
examples: 123 Harbor View Drive, Montego Bay, St. James, Jamaica
45 Technology Park, Kingston 10, Jamaica
Ocean Front Plaza, Unit 12, Negril, Westmoreland, Jamaica

businessDescription.label: Business Description
businessDescription.prompt: Provide a brief description of what your business does and who you serve.
examples: Family-owned restaurant serving authentic Caribbean cuisine to locals and tourists, established 2015, 25 employees, specializing in seafood and traditional Jamaican dishes
Technology consulting firm providing IT support and software development services to small and medium businesses across Jamaica, 12 employees, founded 2018
Tour operator offering cultural and adventure tours throughout Jamaica, serving international tourists and cruise ship passengers, 8 full-time staff plus seasonal guides

keyPersonnel.label: Key Personnel
keyPersonnel.prompt: Who are the key people responsible for business operations and emergency response?
examples: Owner/Manager: John Smith (876-555-0123), Assistant Manager: Maria Rodriguez (876-555-0124), Head Chef: David Williams (876-555-0125)
CEO: Sarah Johnson (876-555-0130), IT Director: Michael Brown (876-555-0131), Operations Manager: Lisa Davis (876-555-0132)
Owner: Robert Taylor (876-555-0140), Tour Coordinator: Angela Thompson (876-555-0141), Safety Officer: Marcus Clarke (876-555-0142)

planPreparedBy.label: Plan Prepared By
planPreparedBy.prompt: Who is preparing this business continuity plan?
examples: John Smith, Business Owner, with assistance from local emergency management office
Emergency Planning Committee: Sarah Johnson (CEO), Michael Brown (IT Director), Lisa Davis (Operations)
Robert Taylor (Owner) and Marcus Clarke (Safety Officer)

preparationDate.label: Preparation Date
preparationDate.prompt: When is this plan being prepared?
examples: January 15, 2024
March 2024
Prepared during Hurricane Season 2024

businessOverview.title: Business Overview
businessOverview.description: Now let's understand your business operations in detail.

businessLicense.label: Business License Number
businessLicense.prompt: What is your business license number? This is usually found on your business registration documents.

businessPurpose.label: Business Purpose
businessPurpose.prompt: What is the main purpose of your business? Think about why you started this business and what problem it solves for your customers.
examples: Provide fresh local products to the St. George's community
Offer affordable home repair services in Barbados
Create authentic Caribbean cuisine for tourists and locals in Montego Bay

productsAndServices.label: Products and Services
productsAndServices.prompt: What products and services do you provide? What makes your business special or unique?
examples: We sell fresh fruits, vegetables, and local spices. Our specialty is homemade hot sauce made with local scotch bonnet peppers.
We provide plumbing and electrical services. What makes us special is our 24/7 emergency service and same-day repairs.
We offer authentic Caribbean cuisine with a modern twist. Our specialty is our family jerk chicken recipe passed down for three generations.

serviceDeliveryMethods.label: Service Delivery Methods
serviceDeliveryMethods.prompt: How and where do you provide your products and services? Consider your physical location, delivery methods, and any online presence.
examples: Physical store in downtown Kingston with delivery to nearby parishes. Customers can order via our website or WhatsApp.
We operate from our workshop but provide services at client locations. We have a mobile service van for emergency calls.
Restaurant in Bridgetown with takeout and delivery. We also offer catering for events and have a food truck for festivals.

operatingHours.label: Operating Hours
operatingHours.prompt: What are your business hours and days of operation? Include any seasonal variations or special hours.
examples: Monday to Saturday, 8 AM to 6 PM. Closed Sundays and holidays. Extended hours during Carnival season.
24/7 for emergency services. Regular business hours Monday to Friday, 9 AM to 5 PM.
Tuesday to Sunday, 11 AM to 10 PM. Extended hours during tourist season (December to April).

keyPersonnel.label: Key Personnel Involved
keyPersonnel.prompt: Who are the key people involved in running your business? Include employees, key suppliers, and contractors.
examples: 3 full-time employees, 2 part-time staff, main supplier (Caribbean Foods Ltd), delivery contractor
Owner-operator, 1 assistant, apprentice electrician, regular parts supplier (Island Hardware)
Head chef, 2 cooks, 3 waiters, manager, local farmers for produce, seafood supplier

minimumResources.label: Minimum Resource Requirements
minimumResources.prompt: What are the absolute minimum resources (staff, equipment, records) needed to keep your business running?
examples: 1 cashier, cash register, refrigeration for perishables, basic inventory, customer payment records
1 qualified technician, basic tool kit, work van, customer contact list, license documents
1 cook, basic kitchen equipment, main menu ingredients, seating for 20 customers, food safety certificates

customerBase.label: Customer Base
customerBase.prompt: Who are your customers? Describe your main customer groups and any special customers who depend on you.
examples: Local families, small restaurants, elderly customers who rely on delivery, tourists
Homeowners in suburban areas, small businesses, property management companies, emergency service calls
Tourists (60%), local residents (30%), special event and catering clients (10%)

serviceProviderBCP.label: Service Provider BCP Status
serviceProviderBCP.prompt: Do your main service providers (suppliers, vendors, contractors) have business continuity plans in place?

options.label: Yes - Most of our key suppliers have shared their continuity plans with us
No - We have not asked our suppliers about their continuity plans
Partially - Some suppliers have plans, others do not
Unknown - We are not sure if our suppliers have continuity plans

essentialFunctions.title: Essential Functions
essentialFunctions.description: Let's identify and prioritize the key functions that keep your business running.

businessFunctions.label: Business Functions
businessFunctions.prompt: List all the main functions of your business. For each function, assess how critical it is and how much downtime you can tolerate.
businessFunctions.tableRowsPromptPartial: Think about all the activities your business performs daily

priorityOptions.label: Critical - Business cannot function without this
Important - Would cause significant problems if stopped
Useful - Good to have but not essential
Deferrable - Can be postponed if necessary

examples: Sales - Process customer orders - Critical - 0-2 hours - Cashier, payment system, inventory
Accounting - Record transactions - Important - 1-3 days - Accountant, accounting software, receipts
Marketing - Social media management - Useful - 3-7 days - Marketing staff, internet access

riskAssessment.title: Risk Assessment
riskAssessment.description: Let's identify and assess the risks that could disrupt your business operations.

potentialHazards.label: Potential Hazards
potentialHazards.prompt: Select all hazards that may affect your business. Consider both natural disasters and human-caused risks that are relevant to your location and industry.
examples: Coastal business: Hurricane, Coastal flooding, Tsunami, Power outage
Technology business: Power outage, Cyber attack, Telecom failure
Retail business: Crime, Fire, Power outage, Supply disruption

riskMatrix.label: Risk Assessment Matrix
riskMatrix.prompt: For each hazard you selected, assess the likelihood and potential severity of impact on your business.
examples: Hurricane - Likely (3) - Serious (3) - High (9) - Purchase insurance, prepare shutters, secure inventory
Power Outage - Very Likely (4) - Minor (2) - Medium (8) - Install backup generator, UPS for computers
Fire - Unlikely (2) - Major (4) - Medium (8) - Install fire alarms, sprinkler system, fire extinguishers

strategies.title: Business Continuity Strategies
strategies.description: Now let's develop comprehensive strategies to prevent, respond to, and recover from the risks you've identified.

preventionStrategies.label: Prevention Strategies (Before Emergencies)
preventionStrategies.prompt: Which prevention strategies will you implement to reduce the likelihood or impact of risks? Select all that apply.

options.label: Regular maintenance of equipment and facilities
Regular data backup and off-site storage
Regular risk assessments and plan updates
Community partnerships and mutual aid agreements

examples: Retail store: Physical security, Insurance, Employee training, Emergency supplies
Technology business: Cybersecurity, Data backup, Employee training, Financial reserves
Restaurant: Maintenance, Insurance, Emergency supplies, Building upgrades

responseStrategies.label: Response Strategies (During Emergencies)
responseStrategies.prompt: Which response strategies will you implement during an emergency? Select all that apply.
examples: Service business: Emergency team, Remote work, Customer continuity, Emergency communication
Retail business: Safety procedures, Emergency inventory, Closure procedures, Emergency services
Manufacturing: Emergency team, Alternative locations, Essential operations, Emergency finance

recoveryStrategies.label: Recovery Strategies (After Emergencies)
recoveryStrategies.prompt: Which recovery strategies will help you restore normal operations after an emergency? Select all that apply.
examples: Small business: Insurance claims, Business resumption, Customer retention, Financial assistance
Service business: Employee support, Customer retention, Reputation management, Lessons learned
Manufacturing: Damage assessment, Facility repair, Equipment replacement, Supplier restoration

longTermMeasures.label: Long-term Risk Reduction Measures
longTermMeasures.prompt: What long-term measures will you implement to reduce future risks? Consider climate adaptation, sustainable practices, and building resilience over time.
examples: Install solar panels for energy independence, relocate critical equipment above flood levels, diversify supply chains across multiple islands
Implement sustainable waste management, use local suppliers to reduce transportation risks, build stronger community partnerships
Invest in climate-resilient building materials, develop staff cross-training programs, establish emergency fund equivalent to 3 months operating costs

actionPlan.title: Smart Action Plan
actionPlan.description: Based on your business type and risk assessment, we've generated a customized action plan. Review and modify as needed.

smartActionPlans.label: Auto-Generated Action Plans
smartActionPlans.prompt: We've analyzed your business type and high-priority risks to create customized action plans. Please review the generated plans below and modify any details that don't fit your specific situation.
examples: Plans are automatically customized based on your business type (tourism, retail, manufacturing, etc.)
Each plan includes immediate, short-term, and medium-term actions with specific responsibilities
Resource requirements and timelines are tailored to your business size and location

implementationPriority.label: Implementation Priority
implementationPriority.prompt: Which action plans would you like to implement first? Consider your current resources and most critical risks.
examples: Start with Hurricane preparedness (highest risk), then Power Outage backup systems
Focus on Cyber Security measures first, then Physical Security improvements
Begin with immediate actions across all risks, then prioritize by business impact

budgetResources.label: Budget and Resources
budgetResources.prompt: What is your estimated budget for implementing these action plans? Include both financial and human resources.
examples: Total budget: $15,000 over 6 months, plus 20 hours/week from management team
Phase 1: $5,000 for immediate needs, Phase 2: $10,000 for infrastructure upgrades
Limited budget ($3,000), will focus on training and procedures before equipment

implementationTeam.label: Implementation Team
implementationTeam.prompt: Who will lead the implementation of your business continuity plan? Assign specific roles and responsibilities.
examples: Project Manager: Operations Manager, Emergency Coordinator: HR Director, Communication Lead: Marketing Manager
Implementation Team: Owner (overall lead), Assistant Manager (daily operations), Senior Staff (training coordination)
Rotating leadership: Manager handles high-risk items, Assistant Manager coordinates staff training, External consultant for technical systems

responsibleParties.label: Responsible Parties and Roles
responsibleParties.prompt: Who will be responsible for implementing and maintaining different aspects of the plan? Assign specific roles and backup responsibilities.
examples: Plan Coordinator: General Manager (backup: Operations Supervisor). IT Systems: IT Manager (backup: External consultant). Staff Training: HR Manager (backup: Senior Supervisor). Emergency Response: Operations Manager (backup: Assistant Manager).

Overall Implementation: Business Owner (backup: Office Manager). Risk Prevention: Facility Manager (backup: Maintenance Staff). Communication: Customer Service Manager (backup: Reception Staff). Financial: Accountant (backup: Office Manager).

Business Continuity Team: 3 senior staff members with rotating leadership. Department Implementation: Each department head responsible for their area. External Relations: Marketing Manager for media, Admin Manager for government/insurance.

reviewSchedule.label: Review and Update Schedule
reviewSchedule.prompt: How often will you review and update your business continuity plan? Include regular reviews and trigger events for updates.
examples: Quarterly reviews of risk assessment and contact information. Annual comprehensive plan update. Immediate review after any emergency event or significant business change.
Monthly check-ins during hurricane season (June-November). Bi-annual full reviews in January and July. Update plan whenever we change suppliers, move locations, or change key staff.
Ongoing monitoring: Monthly risk assessment updates. Formal reviews: Quarterly team meetings. Major updates: Annually and after any emergency event, business expansion, or regulatory changes.

testingPlan.label: Testing and Assessment Plan
testingPlan.prompt: How will you test your business continuity plan to ensure it works effectively?
testingPlan.tableRowsPrompt: Plan different types of tests to validate your business continuity plan.
examples: Communication Test - Monthly - All staff - Everyone receives and responds to emergency message within 2 hours - Communications Manager
Evacuation Drill - Quarterly - All staff and customers - Building evacuated safely within 5 minutes - Safety Officer
Backup System Test - Monthly - IT staff - All systems switch to backup power/internet successfully - IT Manager
Full Plan Exercise - Annually - All key staff - Complete scenario exercise completed successfully - Plan Coordinator

contactsAndInformation.title: Contacts and Critical Information
contactsAndInformation.description: Let's compile all the important contact information and details you'll need during an emergency.

staffContacts.label: Staff Contact Information
staffContacts.prompt: Provide contact information for all staff members.
staffContacts.tableRowsPrompt: Include all employees, managers, and key personnel who would need to be contacted during an emergency.
examples: John Smith - Manager - 876-555-0123 - j.smith@company.com - Wife: 876-555-0124
Maria Rodriguez - Cashier - 876-555-0125 - m.rodriguez@company.com - Sister: 876-555-0126
David Thompson - Cook - 876-555-0127 - d.thompson@company.com - Mother: 876-555-0128

keyCustomers.label: Key Customer Contacts
keyCustomers.prompt: List your most important customers who would need special attention during an emergency.
keyCustomers.tableRowsPrompt: Focus on customers who depend on you for essential services or have special needs.
examples: Mrs. James - Elderly customer (home delivery) - 876-555-0130 - - Relies on weekly grocery delivery
Paradise Resort - Major client - 876-555-0131 - orders@paradiseresort.com - Daily fresh produce delivery
City Hospital - Emergency supplies - 876-555-0132 - procurement@cityhospital.gov - Critical medical supplies

supplierInfo.prompt: List your main suppliers and at least one backup supplier for key goods/services.
supplierInfo.tableRowsPrompt: Include primary suppliers and identify backup options for critical supplies.
examples: Caribbean Foods Ltd - Fresh produce - 876-555-0140 - orders@caribbeanfoods.com - Island Fresh Co.
Island Hardware - Tools & supplies - 876-555-0141 - sales@islandhardware.com - Tools & More Ltd.
Power Solutions Inc - Generator maintenance - 876-555-0142 - service@powersolutions.com - Electric Pro Services

emergencyServices.prompt: Compile contact information for emergency services and utility providers.
emergencyServices.tableRowsPrompt: Include all essential services you might need to contact during an emergency.
examples: Police - Royal Police Force - 911 / 876-555-0150 - - N/A
Fire Department - Kingston Fire Brigade - 911 / 876-555-0151 - - N/A
Electricity - Jamaica Public Service - 876-555-0152 - customer@jps.com.jm - Account: JPS123456
Water - National Water Commission - 876-555-0153 - service@nwc.com.jm - Account: NWC789012
Internet - Flow Jamaica - 876-555-0154 - support@flow.com - Account: FLOW345678
Insurance - Guardian Life - 876-555-0155 - claims@guardian.com - Policy: GL901234

criticalBusinessInfo.label: Critical Business Information
criticalBusinessInfo.prompt: Provide other critical business information needed during emergencies.
examples: Business License: BL-2023-0456, Insurance Policy: GL-789012 (Guardian Life), Bank Account: Scotia Bank #123456789, Critical Records Location: Fireproof safe in manager office, Backup Records: Cloud storage (Google Drive) + external drive at owner home

Registration Number: REG-2022-0789, Insurance: Sagicor Policy #SG-456789, Banking: First Caribbean #987654321, Important Documents: Safety deposit box at bank, Digital Copies: Dropbox account shared with accountant

planDistribution.label: Plan Distribution List
planDistribution.prompt: Track who has received copies of this business continuity plan.
planDistribution.tableRowsPrompt: Document everyone who should have access to the plan.
examples: John Smith (Manager) - Electronic + Hard copy - 2024-01-15 - Version 1.0 - Signed
Maria Rodriguez (Assistant Manager) - Electronic - 2024-01-15 - Version 1.0 - Email confirmed
Guardian Life Insurance - Electronic - 2024-01-20 - Version 1.0 - Submitted with application

testingAndMaintenance.title: Testing and Maintenance
testingAndMaintenance.description: Establish procedures for keeping your business continuity plan current and effective.

testingSchedule.label: Plan Testing Schedule
testingSchedule.prompt: Create a schedule for regularly testing different aspects of your business continuity plan.
testingSchedule.tableRowsPrompt: Plan different types of tests to ensure your plan works when needed.
examples: Communication Test - Emergency contact procedures - Monthly - 2024-02-15 - Office Manager
Backup Systems - Generator and backup power - Quarterly - 2024-03-15 - Maintenance Staff
Evacuation Drill - Emergency evacuation procedures - Semi-annually - 2024-06-15 - Safety Officer
Full Plan Exercise - Complete emergency scenario - Annually - 2024-12-15 - General Manager

revisionHistory.label: Plan Revision History
revisionHistory.prompt: Track changes and updates to your business continuity plan over time.
revisionHistory.tableRowsPrompt: Start with Version 1.0 and plan for future updates.
examples: Version 1.0 - 2024-01-15 - Initial plan creation - John Smith (Manager) - New business continuity plan
Version 1.1 - 2024-03-15 - Updated supplier contacts - Maria Rodriguez - Supplier changed phone numbers
Version 2.0 - 2024-07-15 - Major revision after hurricane drill - John Smith (Manager) - Lessons learned from testing

improvementTracking.label: Improvement Tracking
improvementTracking.prompt: Track improvements and action items identified through testing and real events.
improvementTracking.tableRowsPrompt: Use this to track ongoing improvements to your plan.
examples: Staff took too long to respond to emergency call - Improve staff training on emergency procedures - High - 2024-02-28 - In Progress
Backup generator failed to start - Schedule monthly generator testing and maintenance - High - 2024-01-30 - Completed
Customer contact list was outdated - Implement quarterly customer contact review - Medium - 2024-03-31 - Planned

annualReview.label: Annual Review Process
annualReview.prompt: Describe your process for conducting comprehensive annual reviews of the business continuity plan.
examples: Every January: 1) Review all contact information and update as needed, 2) Assess new risks based on previous year events, 3) Update insurance and financial information, 4) Review staff training needs, 5) Update emergency supplies inventory, 6) Schedule year's testing activities.

Annual review meeting in December with all key staff: Review past year's incidents and tests, update risk assessment based on climate/business changes, verify all contact information, assess budget for next year's improvements, plan training schedule, update emergency supply lists.

Comprehensive annual review process: 1) Stakeholder feedback collection, 2) Risk environment assessment, 3) Plan effectiveness evaluation, 4) Resource requirement review, 5) Training program assessment, 6) Communication system evaluation, 7) Documentation updates.

triggerEvents.label: Trigger Events for Plan Updates
triggerEvents.prompt: What events or changes would trigger an immediate update to your business continuity plan?
examples: Immediate updates required for: 1) Any actual emergency or disaster affecting the business, 2) Changes in key staff or management, 3) Moving to new location or major facility changes, 4) Changes in major suppliers or service providers, 5. New significant risks identified, 6) Changes in insurance coverage or legal requirements.

Plan updates triggered by: Major staff changes, location moves, new equipment/technology, supplier changes, insurance policy changes, government regulation changes, community emergency plan updates, lessons learned from actual emergencies.

Update triggers: Business expansion or downsizing, new technology implementation, changes in customer base, regulatory changes, natural disaster events (even if business not directly affected), changes in local emergency services, merger or acquisition activities.

welcome.title: Business Continuity Plan Generator
welcome.subtitle: Powered by CARICHAM Methodology
welcome.description: This interactive tool helps small and medium businesses create comprehensive emergency preparedness plans. Using the proven CARICHAM methodology, it guides you through identifying risks, planning responses, and building resilience for your business.
welcome.step1: Tell us about your business type and location for personalized recommendations
welcome.step2: Answer guided questions with industry-specific examples and suggestions
welcome.step3: Download your complete, professional business continuity plan as a PDF
welcome.businessInfo: Basic information about your business operations
welcome.saveProgress: You can save progress and return anytime
welcome.comprehensivePlan: A complete, professional business continuity plan
welcome.industrySpecific: Tailored recommendations for your business type
welcome.pdfDownload: Downloadable PDF ready for banks, insurers, and stakeholders
welcome.dataSecure: Your data is secure and private
welcome.privacyNote: All information is stored locally and encrypted. No personal data is required.

help.businessPurpose: Explain what your business does and why it exists. This helps identify what's most important to protect during emergencies.
help.productsAndServices: List your main products or services. Think about what generates revenue and what customers depend on you for.
help.keyPersonnelInvolved: Identify people whose absence would significantly impact operations. Include owners, managers, and specialists with unique skills.
help.customerBase: Describe who your typical customers are and how they find/contact you. This affects how you communicate during disruptions.
help.minimumResourceRequirements: List the absolute minimum staff, equipment, and resources needed to operate at a basic level during emergencies.
help.operatingHours: Include regular hours, seasonal variations, and any special schedules. This affects when you're vulnerable to disruptions.
help.businessFunctions: Think about core activities (what customers pay for), support activities (what keeps core running), and admin tasks (legal, financial).
help.potentialHazards: Consider both natural disasters common to your area and human-caused risks that could affect your business.
help.preventionStrategies: Actions you take now to reduce the chance of problems occurring. Examples: backup systems, insurance, maintenance schedules.
help.responseStrategies: What you'll do when an emergency actually happens. Focus on immediate actions to protect people and minimize damage.
help.recoveryStrategies: Steps to get back to normal operations after an emergency. Consider temporary solutions and long-term rebuilding.
help.emergencyContacts: Key people to call during emergencies. Include suppliers, employees, emergency services, and business partners.
help.communicationProcedures: How you'll stay in touch with employees, customers, and suppliers when normal communication is disrupted.
help.backupProcedures: Backup plans for critical systems, data, and processes. Include where backups are stored and how to access them.
help.insurancePolicies: Important insurance information including policy numbers, coverage details, and contact information for quick access.
help.testingSchedule: Regular testing ensures your plan works when needed. Include frequency, who's responsible, and what gets tested.
help.reviewSchedule: Plans need updates as your business changes. Set regular review dates and triggers for unscheduled updates.
